For the state affordable-housing law: Mount Laurel was incorporated as a township by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on March 7
column3: from portions of Evesham Township. The township was named for a hill covered with laurel trees.There are several historical landmarks
column8: Hattie Britt School and Farmer's Hall.

For the state affordable-housing law: The Mount Laurel Decision is a judicial interpretation of the New Jersey State Constitution that requires municipalities to use their zoning powers in an affirmative manner to provide a realistic opportunity for the production of housing affordable to low and moderate income households. The decision was a result of a lawsuit brought against the town by the N.A.A.C.P. that was decided by the New Jersey Supreme Court in 1975 and reaffirmed in a subsequent decision in 1983.The history behind this
and the story leading to the Decision was highlighted in Our Town
column3: a book by David L. Kirp.Mount Laurel was a small
column4: rural farming community until it was hit with massive suburban growth from Philadelphia in the later 1960s. Some families
column5: whose history had resided there for centuries
column6: were suddenly priced out of buying property. In 1970
column7: at a meeting about a proposal for affordable housing
column8: held at an all black church in Mount Laurel
column9: Mayor Bill Haines summed up the newcomers' perspective by saying: "If you people can't afford to live in our town
column10: then you'll just have to leave."Even though the black families in Mount Laurel were not from urban ghettos
column11: and were not involved in gang activity
column12: the new suburban influx thought otherwise
column13: and significantly delayed the creation of affordable housing areas
column14: citing concerns of gang activity and an influx of inner city criminals. Exampled comments from town meetings against forced construction of housing projects included "we need this like Custer needed more Indians"; "it's reverse discrimination"; "we lived in this in South Philly and Newark"
column15: and that the housing would be a "breeding ground for violent crime and drug abuse".Resident advocates of the housing initiative were treated with abuse and threats. Leading advocate Ethel Lawrence
column16: a black resident who lived her life in Mount Laurel
column18: and once her bedroom window was damaged by gunfire. Longtime white residents also tried to force the black residents out of town. Although the court ruled in favor of creating affordable housing
column19: residents did manage to delay the process for decades.

column3: including 21.72 square miles (56.26 km2) of land and 0.27 square miles (0.69 km2) of water (1.21%). It is drained by the Delaware River and Parkers Creek (a tributary of Rancocas Creek) and the South Branch Pennsauken Creek flow through its eastern and western portions respectively.

For the state affordable-housing law: Mount Laurel has a humid subtropical climate (Cfa) and average monthly temperatures range from 33.0° F in January to 76.9° F in July. The local hardiness zone is 7a.

fishing lake
column3: playground
column4: and huge grassy hill used for concerts and sledding in the winter when it snows. Laurel Acres Park is right between Church Street at Union Mill Road. The Mount Laurel Baseball League and the Mount Laurel United Soccer Club play in the park's sports fields

For the state affordable-housing law: Mount Laurel voted to change its form of government in 1970 from a Township Committee form to a Faulkner Act system using the Council-Manager (Plan E)
enacted based on the recommendations of a Charter Study Commission as of January 1
column3: 1972. The township is one of 42 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form of government. In this form of government
column4: the Township Manager oversees the daily functions of the Township. The governing body is comprised of the Township Council
column5: which is made up of five members elected at-large in partisan elections to serve four-year terms on a staggered basis
column6: with either two or three seats coming up for election in even-numbered years as part of the November general election. At an annual reorganization meeting held in January
column7: the council selects one of its members to serve as mayor and another to serve as deputy mayor
column8: each for a one-year term.As of 2020
column9: members of the Mount Laurel Township Council are Mayor Irwin Edelson (R
column10: term on council and as mayor ends December 31
column13: term on council ends 2020; term as deputy mayor ends 2019)

For the state affordable-housing law: The Mount Laurel Schools serve public school students in pre-kindergarten through eighth grade. The grade configuration includes six schools serving pre-kindergarten / kindergarten through fourth-grade students. Students are assigned on a geographic basis to one of the six K-4 schools; Countryside serves the township's northwest; Fleetwood
the northeast; Hillside covers the north central portion of the township; Larchmont
column3: a piece of the eastern side; Parkway
column4: covers the western portion; and Springville the southern tip. All students from the six K-4 schools feed into a single upper elementary school (for grades 5 and 6) and middle school (grades 7 and 8). As of the 2018–19 school year
column8: 214 students and 350.0 classroom teachers (on an FTE basis)
column9: for a student–teacher ratio of 12.0:1. Schools in the district (with 2018–19 enrollment data from the National Center for Education Statistics) are

awarded by the United States Department of Education

the township had a total of 170.19 miles (273.89 km) of roadways
column3: of which 115.86 miles (186.46 km) were maintained by the municipality
column4: 33.26 miles (53.53 km) by Burlington County and 13.55 miles (21.81 km) by the New Jersey Department of Transportation and 7.52 miles (12.10 km) by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.The New Jersey Turnpike is the most prominent highway passing through Mount Laurel. It enters from Cherry Hill in the township's southwest corner and continues for about 7.5 miles (12.1 km) to Westampton Township at Mount Laurel's northern edge. The Turnpike's James Fenimore Cooper rest area is located within the township on the northbound side at milepost 39.4. The only exit within Mount Laurel is Exit 4
column5: which provides access to Route 73.Interstate 295 passes through the township
